ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

RESTRUCTURED HOSPITALS
(Operational cost)


    1. Mr Yeo Toon Chia asked the Minister for Health (a) what is the operational cost of running restructured hospitals, giving a breakdown of the profit/loss of these hospitals from 1990 to 1992 and (b) whether there will be an increase in the charges of these hospitals and, if so, what measures his Ministry is taking to curb the rising charges.

     The Minister for Health (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the total operational cost of running the Singapore General Hospital, Kandang Kerbau Hospital, Toa Payoh Hospital and the National University Hospital for 1990, 1991 and 1992 are as follows:

    The net surplus of $26 million in 1992 was mainly due to an increase in the subsidy received by NUH. This was because NUH's subsidy in earlier years was under-computed by about $10 million and this shortfall was paid to the hospital in 1992.

    Sir, manpower costs account for 65% of the operating costs of hospitals. As long as Singaporeans enjoy good pay increases, medical cost must rise accordingly. This is because hospitals also have to pay competitive wage increases in order to be able to recruit and retain their

Column: 1342

staff. It is therefore better that hospitals increase their fees by small amounts every year to cover their cost increases, rather than to defer such revisions and have large increases every few years.

    The hospitals will, however, continue to improve and streamline their operating systems and procedures, and optimise on the use of manpower. Other measures which the hospitals are taking to control costs include:

    a) Restricting the purchase and regulating the use of expensive medical equipment;

    b) Controlling the use of expensive drugs;

    c) Automating labour intensive procedures; and

    d) Avoid duplication of services amongst hospitals.

    Since hospital operating costs will continue to increase, it is inevitable that part of the cost increases be absorbed by the patients. However, for subsidised patients, because of Government subsidies, much of these cost increases will be borne by the Government. The Government will pay for as much as 80% of the cost increases for Class C patients and 65% of the cost increases for B2 patients.

     Mr Yeo Toon Chia (Ang Mo Kio GRC): Sir, could the Minister ask the restructured hospitals to present statements of accounts to Parliament?

Column: 1343



     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, the hospitals are private companies owned by the Government and their accounts are published every year. If Members of Parliament wish to have them, I can arrange for Members to receive their annual reports.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Cheng San GRC): Sir, may I ask the Minister what was the percentage of manpower cost of these restructured hospitals before they were restructured?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, the manpower cost of the hospitals appeared to be higher before they were restructured. In fact, the manpower cost amounted to slightly over 70%. This is because a fair bit of the operating cost was actually hidden subsidies provided by the Government. By restructuring, we were able to recognise these hidden subsidies and therefore the manpower cost, as a percentage of the total operating cost, went down to 65%.

     Dr Toh Keng Kiat (Nominated Member): Sir, does the Minister envisage an improvement of the deficit situation now that there will be a revision of the Consultation Fee Scheme?

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, the revision in the Consultation Fee Scheme will in no

Column: 1344

way affect the operating cost. This is because the Consultancy Fee Scheme comes out from more or less a fixed pool of money. The revision only affects how that sum of money is to be distributed amongst the doctors.

    Resumption of Debate on Question [16th March, 1993],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head R of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Mr Peter Sung].

    Question again proposed.

     The Minister for Information and the Arts (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Sir, yesterday, in my answer to Mr Robert Chua's question about satellite dishes, I gave two reasons why we do not allow such dishes for households. First, control; second, access rights. There is a third reason which is that there will then be a proliferation of dishes on our rooftops pointing in different directions at different satellites. It makes much more sense for us in Singapore to lay a cable network for our whole island and this can easily be done in 5-7 years. We are a compact city. The ducts have already been dug by Telecom and we can either use Telecom's optical fibres or lay new fibres in the ducts which are already there.

    SBC and Telecom engaged a cable consultant last year. The consultant has briefed both Mr Mah Bow Tan and myself. They told us that it is entirely feasible. Every household can easily have access to over 30 to 100 TV channels. In America where cable TV is readily available and, in some cities, already 100 channels, few homes bother to install satellite dishes. If we have a cable network in Singapore, satellite dishes will also not be worth the trouble. In an emergency, this will give us a chance also to reach out to everyone. For example, if the SAF needs to mobilise reservists, then the green man can flash on all the channels. Cable will also allow us to keep out the extremes of pornography and the broadcasts which are incendiary.

Column: 1346



    But will we have time to watch so many channels? What will happen? Will TV increasingly shift from broadcasting to narrow casting as the marginal cost of a channel becomes much lower? TV channels will become more specialised and more targeted. There are sociological implications we have to think through. TV programmes will no longer be a basis for common experience. It will no longer be a common stage for the whole community. One day, if you ask someone, "Have you watched TV last night?" that will be a nonsensical question because which channel are you talking about. It is like asking someone whether he read the book without identifying the title of the book.

    But the benefits are enormous. We will become a much more information and knowledge-intensive society. We will be able to allow the various foreign communities in Singapore to watch their own television channel from Japan, Germany, France and so on. This will help consolidate our position as a hub city for international business. To attract the talent of the world to come to Singapore, we have to cater to their needs.

    Whatever the problems, there is no going back. Whether by satellite, by terrestrial broadcast from Malaysia or Indonesia or by cable, SBC has no choice but to compete regionally and internationally.

    To answer Mr Robert Chua, yes, we will have to broadcast by satellite. It is a matter of time and business calculation. This is why I have been pushing for the privatisation of SBC by the end of next year. We simply have to become more competitive. If we do not swim, we will sink. There is no escaping this choice.

    Channels 5 and 8 will be spun off into one company, Channel 12 into another, Radio into a third, and so on. We will have to strengthen the channel image of each company so that when there are many channels available they can hold their own.

Column: 1347


12.45 pm

    We may even have to reshuffle the broadcast languages so that each channel will have a stronger identity. And there is no escaping the logic of competition and the need to watch ratings. If we do nothing, we will become like Indian television which has been so careful with regulations that it has become virtually irrelevant. And so you find in India today, Star Television, being watched all over, all six channels, including Hindi channels.

    I do not know why the Indian government has allowed this, because if they wanted to control, I am sure the Indian civil service would have found some way to regulate. But they have chosen not to control and I suspect the reason is that the present government has decided to let TV in, in order to break the mindset of over 800 million people, because they are embarked on this course of reform without which India would be left far behind by other countries.

    By itself, competition will bring down standards and lead to more sex and more violence. Therefore, a good regulatory framework is very necessary. When SBC is privatised, a new statutory board will be formed to perform this function. We will have to ensure minimum hours of public service broadcast, news, current affairs, documentaries, minority programmes, children's programmes and so on. And we will do this with a combination of licensing fees and by direct State subventions. Licence fees and State subsidies will go to the statutory board for allocation to the different channels. And we must also support local productions so that we are not only importers of programmes, we are also exporters. But even in the best situation, we can never hope to produce more than a fraction of all the programmes that we broadcast.

    Locally-produced serials have been a tremendous success. We are now exporting them all over the world. I have seen SBC Chinese serials in Vancouver. I have seen them in Islamabad. I have even seen them in Urumqi in Xinjiang. We have

Column: 1348

come a long way. Without Hong Kong talent, we would not have been able to achieve this. I hear many criticisms of Hong Kong producers and I understand the reasons for these criticisms. But I think we must give credit where credit is due.

    SBC is going into English dramas. We had our first feature a few days ago. It was not bad. There is promise. And I hope that in 5-10 years our English dramas will reach the standard of our Chinese dramas.

    Let me now turn to the issue of censorship. I spent some time explaining the challenges confronting television in Singapore because that provides the context, the background, behind SBC's drive to experiment and to try new things. Sometimes they make mistakes which I expect them to. If they do not make mistakes, that means they have stopped trying and that is no good. We become like Indian television. But every time they make mistakes, we must inform them. Then they will adjust, pull back and improve.

    SBC has to strike a balance between the desire to entertain and the need to also inform and educate. I saw parts of "Angel of Vengeance" when I came back from India and I felt uncomfortable which was why when Prof. Jayakumar mentioned it to me, I immediately proposed that we set up a Police/SBC Committee. And I was relieved when I spoke to the General Manager of SBC to learn that he was also unhappy and even before I raised the matter with him, he had already raised the matter with his staff in order that they make adjustments and corrections.

    Yes, I know some people say, "Look, there is no clear nexus between TV violence and crime." But if there is no clear nexus, we must always err on the side of safety.

    Of all the mediums, we are strictest with television because it goes right into the living room. The Government accepted the recommendation of the Censorship Review Committee that TV be censored more strictly than cinemas. In September, I asked the Chairman of SBC, Dr Cheong Choong Kong, to do an independent audit

Column: 1349

of SBC's censorship standards. He, in turn, persuaded Mr Hsuan Owyang, who is the Chairman of our Board of Film Appeals, to be the Chairman of the TV censorship panel. The other members were Mr Chua Gim Siong, Prof. Eddie Kuo, Mr Ronald Lim, Mr Arun Mahizhnan and Mr Suhaimi Salleh. They are all not from SBC. So they could give an independent perspective. And they are people known to have conservative views which was why they were chosen.

    Let me quote a few passages from their report. They said:

    'The panel agreed that stricter censorship involving morality should be applied to local productions. The impact of local productions is expected to be greater as viewers can easily identify with them.' For example, it is one thing seeing violence by Sylvester Stallone and Arnold Schwarzenegger, but it is quite another to see violence by Zoe Tay and Li Nanxing, especially in Bedok or Toa Payoh. There is an immediacy which is not there when we watch Hollywood or even Hong Kong.

    `The panel was also satisfied with the level of censorship applied to the treatment of violence in programmes. A few exceptions were noted such as excessive violence in some action dramas and movies.' It maintained that:

    'the level of violence in programmes should continue to be kept low as the cumulative effect of violence on TV is not fully known.'

    The panel advised in the end that:

    'in managing the censorship process, SBC should be conscious of its own social responsibility as well as prevailing public expectations. Thus, liberalisation must be done in a careful and gradual manner. However, it cautioned against reverting to an over conservative stance in view of the advances in technology and changing social norms.' I have asked SBC to release the report.

    I disagree with Mr Peter Sung that each time the limit of censorship is pushed, we extend the limits. That is not true at all. We are policing the limits all the time. On homosexual scenes in "Breaking Point", we asked SBC to pull back last year. On violence, we are asking SBC to pull back now. It is to police the same limits that

Column: 1350

MITA banned the book Harlots and the latest issue of the magazine Marie Claire. Cosmopolitan wanted to bring in a special edition for Singapore. They say, "Don't look at the American, British or Australian editions. Look at the South African edition which is more conservative." So we took a look but we found it to be excessive. And, in fact, over the last few months, some issues of the South African Cosmopolitan have been banned by the South African government. So we are not rushing at all. They can wait.

    It is not true what Mr Peter Sung said that school girls can legally view R(A) videos like "The Lover". This is against the law. R(A) films can only be screened in approved cinemas and duplication is not allowed. It is a punishable offence.

    I think Dr Vasoo must have been misled by the advertisements he sees in the newspapers. R(A) films are a small proportion of all the films shown, maybe one in eight, one in 10, and they are allowed to be screened only in licensed cinemas and none of these are in HDB estates.

    Both Mr Hsuan Owyang's TV Censorship Panel and Prof. Tommy Koh's Censorship Review Committee (CRC) did sterling work. Censorship is a very subjective matter. No two persons will agree entirely. The CRC members who covered a wide span, including religious leaders, started with very diverse views but were able in the end to produce a consensus report which was balanced and comprehensive. And I think we see widespread approval. I was therefore quite surprised by the harsh criticism of the CRC by Mr Peh Chin Hua and some others.

    Let me clarify a few points. The CRC recommended NC16 not as a relaxation but as a tightening. It was precisely Dr Vasoo's concerns that they wanted to address, that parents might not be around to guide their children, and this was why they suggested that some PG films be banned for children below 16. And this is what NC16 is about, not a relaxation but a tightening.

Column: 1351



    The CRC cannot be held responsible for the publication of Action for AIDS. It is true that one of the issues was unnecessarily explicit in recommending the use of condoms. In fact, it was my Minister of State, Dr Ker Sin Tze, who pointed it out to MITA officials who then immediately called up the publishers to tell them to stop circulating it to the schools. The other day I asked Mr Yeo Cheow Tong about this organisation Action for AIDS (ASA). Is it a serious organisation? Mr Yeo told me that they are doing good work. They reach out to groups which could not otherwise be reached. If the ASA takes too moralistic a stand, they will not reach out to these groups. And God knows that AIDS is a very serious problem that we have to address. But, of course, we must at the same time not allow publicity on AIDS to go too far, which is why we have not allowed Chris Ho's music video "Safe Sex" which claims to be sex education with respect to AIDS.

    But I am very heartened by the principled position taken by Mr Peter Sung, Mr Peh Chin Hua, Dr Vasoo and Mr Goh Choon Kang. They are talking not only about censorship, they are talking about morals in society. It is important to take a stand and to distinguish between right and wrong, and censorship is only a part of the problem.

    Technology is making censorship harder and harder to enforce. Despite all of Government's efforts, we can only stop a part of the traffic in pornography. We must not think that just because we bury our heads in the sand and we see nothing ourselves that others see nothing and nothing is happening. We can check magazines and books, but we will need an army of censors to vet all videos, CDs and software tapes. Any copies smuggled in can be easily replicated. The machines are readily available. And with a Handycam, you can produce your own videos. With electronic bulletin boards today, you can dial up IDD directly and get your pornography flicks from America or Europe. These things are brought about by technology and technology has not yet

Column: 1352

given us a way to bring about foolproof controls. What we can do is to crack down and crack down hard on distributors. It is not practical to try to catch all individual offenders. In fact, we are looking at new legislation to broaden the definition of "distribution" and to increase the penalties so that it is not worth the while for those who want to make money to make money this way.

    Censorship is important because it establishes the standards a society sets for itself. It is a signal that we send to everyone. But censorship is never enough. And sometimes you do not need censorship. If you look at Chinese families in the Chinatowns in America, mostly in red light areas, or Indian families living in depressed areas of Britain, surrounded by drugs and violence, their children see what is happening, but they grow up, sturdy and upright. Why is this? It is because of the family, is it not? And that is the critical factor.

    There was an article in Britain recently about an Indian family in a poor part of London. They run a small shop. They caught English kids stealing. They informed the parents. The parents, instead of whacking the kids, were not happy that they were told. That is the trouble, is it not, when the family abdicates its responsibility to educate the next generation.

    The family plays a critical role. It is right that Singapore should be stricter than most other cities in Asia even though Singaporeans travel extensively. It is right that when we come back to Singapore we take off our shoes and we put on slippers because Singapore is home. But we must not delude ourselves into thinking that while we can keep out the mud, we can make Singapore a germ-free environment. Singapore cannot be a germ-free environment. What we need is to build up our own immune system and have occasional inoculations. What is decisive are the values we impart in our families, our schools and our civic institutions.
1.00 pm

    I agree with Mr Peter Sung and Dr Wang Kai Yuen that we should learn from the mistakes of the West. In a speech earlier

Column: 1353

this year, Alexander Solzhenitsyn said, very sadly, that the West has been "undergoing an erosion, an obscuring of high moral and ethical standards. The spiritual axis of life has gone dim." The line between right and wrong is being blurred in the West. All lifestyle choices become equally illegitimate. As the Christian says, that is Satan's greatest triumph, when people stop making distinctions between right and wrong.

    I felt uncomfortable when an AFA activist suggested to me, "Look, do not call prostitutes "prostitutes". That is too judgmental. Call them "sex workers"". I found that troubling. I was very troubled when after we banned Marie Claire, the publisher told the press, "Look. We are only reporting. We take no position one way or the other." But that is the point. I think as individuals, as organisations, we should take a stand. It is because we take a stand that we maintain the immune system in our body politic.

    In yesterday's Asian Wall Street Journal, William Bennett, who used to be President Reagan's Education Secretary from 1985-1988, contributed a very dismal piece on America's moral decline. I think it is worth my while quoting a few passages because it is part of a debate between East and West. He said, over the last 30 years:

    `there has been a 560% increase in violent crime; a 419% increase in illegitimate births; a quadrupling in divorce rates; a tripling of the percentage of children living in single-parent homes; more than a 200% increase in the teenage suicide rate; and a drop of almost 80 points in Scholastic Aptitude Test scores.'

    He said that:

    `America's cultural decline is evidence of a shift in the public's attitudes and beliefs. .... American society now places less value than before on what it owes to others as a matter of moral obligations; less value on sacrifice as a moral good; less value on social conformity and respectability; and less value on correctness and restraint in matters of physical pleasure and sexuality.

    The American social and civic institutions - families, churches, schools, neighbourhoods and civic associations - have traditionally taken on the responsibility of providing children with love, order, and discipline - of teaching self-control, compassion, tolerance, civility, honesty, and respect for authority. Government, even at its best, can never be more than an auxiliary in the development of character.'

Column: 1354



    I think it should be against this perspective that we see the whole issue of censorship.

    As Tan Tarn How wrote in the Straits Times recently, we have been deluged with American values. Tan Tarn How thinks that we cannot fight the trend. I think he is wrong. He sees the tidal wave, but he does not see the tidal shift. The values which the West now holds are not the values which created modern Western civilisation. The Calvinist values - strong families, thrift, hard work, education, living for others. In an ironic twist of history, it is now the East which upholds these values. And as East Asia becomes the economic centre of the world, East Asian influence in the world, East Asian methods of business organisation, of social organisation, will spread its influence in the world. If we hold firm, I am confident the tide will turn as we enter the next millennium.

    Let me now turn to Mr Chiam See Tong's proposal for more newspapers in Singapore. We have 11 local and over 30 major foreign newspapers circulating here. Whether there should be more is not for MITA to decide. It is for investors to decide. MITA does not place a limit on the number of newspapers. We also have political newspapers like the SDP's Demokrat, and the Workers' Party's Hammer. I notice that the Demokrat appears infrequently, but that is Mr Chiam's decision. The Hammer appears more frequently. A few Sunday's ago, my wife came back from the market, she brought me a copy of the Hammer, which costs 40 cents. I went through it. I was very sad to find that they decided to extract articles written by foreigners against Singapore, and reprinted in the Hammer. In other words, if they have criticisms against the Government, why do they not find their own writers? Is there such a poverty of ideas and a paucity of writers that you have to use others to be a surrogate? Or do we still have this servile mentality that what the white man says must be right?

    Mr Chiam blames the newspapers for the SDP's dismal performance in the last by-election. First, he blamed dialects. Now

Column: 1355

he blames newspapers. I do not believe that the voters in Marine Parade GRC lacked information in that very private moment when they went to the polling booth. I find it very strange that Mr Chiam considers the Straits Times a PAP newspaper, when it prints all these long rambling letters from the SDP. And despite the SDP shifting its position each time its arguments are punctured, still the Straits Times prints these letters. It is for the Straits Times to decide.

    A few weeks ago, the Sunday Times printed and gave colour coverage to a rather mediocre wall painting in Hougang. Some of our PAP MPs got excited and grumbled to me that the Sunday Times is pro-Opposition. I think that is also not true.
